Now that Ruby 2.7 has added the support for beginless range, Rails 7 also adds support to include the beginless range in ActiveRecord inclusivity/exclusivity validators.

Prior to Rails 7, if we were to add a validation to a Product model where the price needs to be within 5000, we’d have to follow this method-

Before

{% highlight ruby %}

class Product < ApplicationRecord

validates_inclusion_of :price, in: 0..5000

end

{% endhighlight %}

Also, if we would try adding beginless range, then it will throw an error.

{% highlight ruby %}

=> Product.create(title: “Detergent”, description: “A mixture of surfactants with cleansing properties”, price: 4000) /Users/.rvm/gems/ruby-3.0.2/gems/activemodel-7.0.3/lib/active_model/validations/clusivity.rb:45:in `first’: cannot get the first element of beginless range (RangeError)

{% endhighlight %}

As it can be seen, it throws an error saying cannot get the first element of beginless range.

After

After Rails 7, we can now add the beginless range.

{% highlight ruby %}

class Product < ApplicationRecord

validates_inclusion_of :price, in: ..5000

end

{% endhighlight %}

{% highlight ruby %}

=> Product.create(title: “Detergent”, description: “A mixture of surfactants with cleansing properties”, price: 4000) => TRANSACTION (7.5ms) BEGIN Product Create (5.0ms) INSERT INTO “products” (“name”, “description”, “createdat”, “updatedat”, “price”) VALUES (1,1,1,2, 3,3,3,4, $5) RETURNING “id” [[“name”, “Detergent”], [“description”, “A mixture of surfactants with cleansing properties”], [“created_at”, “2022-08-10 20:10:06.227125”], [“updated_at”, “2022-08-10 20:10:06.227125”], [“price”, 4000]] TRANSACTION (2.5ms) COMMIT

{% endhighlight %}

Check out the PR for more details.
